conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves forward while remaining above them.
Object A is a decorative kimono/dress figurine with floral pattern.
Object B is a small white stand/pedestal with what appears to be a postcard.
Object C is another part of the kimono figure.
Object D is a small bottle or container.
Red arrows point to the shadows cast by these objects on the tiled floor.
Physics of shadows when light source moves forward: Shadows will move inward and become smaller.
Shadow A will move inward toward the base of the figurine and become smaller and less elongated.
Shadow B will move inward toward the base of the stand and become smaller and less elongated.
Shadow C will move inward toward the base of the figurine and become smaller and less elongated.
Shadow D will move inward toward the base of the bottle and become smaller and less elongated.
Explanation using shadow geometry: Shadows become minimal when light source is directly above objects.
As the light source moves to an angle, shadows elongate away from the light.
When the light source moves forward, the angle of incoming light becomes steeper, causing shadows to move closer to directly beneath their objects and become smaller.
Final Answer: All shadows will move inward toward the bases of their respective objects and become smaller and less elongated.
